Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite complaint investigation completed on February 2, 2024, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital. At the time of the investigation, the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite complaint investigation completed on February 2, 2024, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital. At the time of the investigation, the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: 123.5 LICENSURE ADMINISTRATION OF ANESTHESIA:123.5  Administration of anesthesia Anesthesia care shall be provided 
by a qualified physician, 
anesthesiologist, resident physician 
in training, dentist anesthetist, 
qualified nurse anesthetist under the 
supervision of the operating physician 
or anesthesiologist, or supervised 
nurse trainees enrolled in a course 
approved by the American Board of 
Nurse Anesthetists.Observations:Based on review of facility documentation, record review (MR), and staff interview (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure that anesthesia was administered by a qualified practitioner for one of one medical records reviewed (MR1).Findings include:A review, on February 2, 2024, at 9:30 A.M., of the facility's Protocol for Patient Management, review date April 2023, revealed... "Ketamine Infusion for Pain Management...ED, ICU, SDU...Protocol for Patient Management...OBJECTIVE,  To outline the nursing management of a patient receiving a ketamine infusion. ...It has been used clinically in sub-anesthetic doses for the treatment of neuropathic and acute and chronic pain syndromes". During an interview on February 2, 2024, at 9:45 A.M., EMP1 confirmed that nurses in the Emergency Department administer Ketamine to patients for pain management.On February 2, 2024, a request was made for a Keatmine Intramuscular (IM) policy. None was provided.A review of MR1 on February 2, 2024,  revealed that the patient received 300 mg of Ketamine IM by Registered Nurse PF1, on January 27, 2024, at 8:12 AM and at 9:15 AM.During an interview on February 2, 2024 at approximately 11:00 AM, EMP1 confirmed the above findings. Plan of Correction - To be completed: 02/15/2024On 2/2/2024, The Chief Nursing Officer, Medical Director of the Emergency Department, Nursing Clinical Director of the Emergency Department, and Regulatory Analyst reviewed the Patient Management, Ketamine Infusion for Pain Management Nursing Protocol.  The team determined that there was no need to revise the protocol.  Additionally, the team determined that the organization does not have a Ketamine Intramuscular policy.  Upon review of the protocol and survey findings, the team concurred, effective February 2, 2024, Ketamine IM will not be administered by a RN in the Emergency Department. This practice change was communicated to all Emergency Department providers and nursing staff via email by the Emergency Department Medical Director on 2/2/2024. The notification also noted that if the physician desires to use Ketamine IM, the physician must give the IM injection and nursing will document such in the electronic medical record as will the physician that administers the drug. To ensure compliance, the Regulatory Analyst will audit the administration of Ketamine IM in the ED daily for the months of February, March, and April utilizing a report developed by the Nursing Informatics Department.  The Regulatory Analyst will review who administered the drug and the documentation of such in the electronic medical record for any administered doses. Compliance will be monitored for 3 months (2/5/24 through 4/30/24) with the expectation of 100% for 3 consecutive months. If performance falls below 100% during this timeframe, ongoing monitoring will continue until such time as it is maintained at 100% for 3 consecutive months. Any episodes of non-compliance will be addressed immediately, and the staff member will be re-educated on the performance expectations. 123.5 LICENSURE ADMINISTRATION OF ANESTHESIA: 123.5  Administration of anesthesia Anesthesia care shall be provided 
by a qualified physician, 
anesthesiologist, resident physician 
in training, dentist anesthetist, 
qualified nurse anesthetist under the 
supervision of the operating physician 
or anesthesiologist, or supervised 
nurse trainees enrolled in a course 
approved by the American Board of 
Nurse Anesthetists. Observations:Based on review of facility documentation, record review (MR), and staff interview (EMP), it was determined the facility failed to ensure that anesthesia was administered by a qualified practitioner for one of one medical records reviewed (MR1).Findings include:A review, on February 2, 2024, at 9:30 A.M., of the facility's Protocol for Patient Management, review date April 2023, revealed... "Ketamine Infusion for Pain Management...ED, ICU, SDU...Protocol for Patient Management...OBJECTIVE,  To outline the nursing management of a patient receiving a ketamine infusion. ...It has been used clinically in sub-anesthetic doses for the treatment of neuropathic and acute and chronic pain syndromes". During an interview on February 2, 2024, at 9:45 A.M., EMP1 confirmed that nurses in the Emergency Department administer Ketamine to patients for pain management.On February 2, 2024, a request was made for a Keatmine Intramuscular (IM) policy. None was provided.A review of MR1 on February 2, 2024,  revealed that the patient received 300 mg of Ketamine IM by Registered Nurse PF1, on January 27, 2024, at 8:12 AM and at 9:15 AM.During an interview on February 2, 2024 at approximately 11:00 AM, EMP1 confirmed the above findings. Plan of Correction - To be completed: 02/15/2024On 2/2/2024, The Chief Nursing Officer, Medical Director of the Emergency Department, Nursing Clinical Director of the Emergency Department, and Regulatory Analyst reviewed the Patient Management, Ketamine Infusion for Pain Management Nursing Protocol.  The team determined that there was no need to revise the protocol.  Additionally, the team determined that the organization does not have a Ketamine Intramuscular policy.  Upon review of the protocol and survey findings, the team concurred, effective February 2, 2024, Ketamine IM will not be administered by a RN in the Emergency Department. This practice change was communicated to all Emergency Department providers and nursing staff via email by the Emergency Department Medical Director on 2/2/2024. The notification also noted that if the physician desires to use Ketamine IM, the physician must give the IM injection and nursing will document such in the electronic medical record as will the physician that administers the drug. To ensure compliance, the Regulatory Analyst will audit the administration of Ketamine IM in the ED daily for the months of February, March, and April utilizing a report developed by the Nursing Informatics Department.  The Regulatory Analyst will review who administered the drug and the documentation of such in the electronic medical record for any administered doses. Compliance will be monitored for 3 months (2/5/24 through 4/30/24) with the expectation of 100% for 3 consecutive months. If performance falls below 100% during this timeframe, ongoing monitoring will continue until such time as it is maintained at 100% for 3 consecutive months. Any episodes of non-compliance will be addressed immediately, and the staff member will be re-educated on the performance expectations.

Initial comments:This report is the result of a Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act Survey conducted on January 16, 2024, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital.  It was determined the facility was in compliance with requirements of the Chapter 5100 Mental Health regulations. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of a Department of Human Services, Chapter 5100 Mental Health Procedures Act Survey conducted on January 16, 2024, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital.  It was determined the facility was in compliance with requirements of the Chapter 5100 Mental Health regulations. Plan of Correction:

Initial comments:This report is the result of a Special Monitoring Closure survey conducted on October 13, 2023, at the Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital's outpatient Quick Draw Plus facility located at 410 Pellis Road, Suite A2, Greensburg, PA 15601. Initial comments:This report is the result of an onsite occupancy survey conducted on September 29, 2023, with continued document review, at the Excela Square Connellsville, Outpatient Services (Specimen Collection facility), located at 854 Vanderbilt Road, Connellsville, PA 15425. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities.  Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an onsite occupancy survey conducted on September 29, 2023, with continued document review, at the Excela Square Connellsville, Outpatient Services (Specimen Collection facility), located at 854 Vanderbilt Road, Connellsville, PA 15425. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities.  Plan of Correction:

Initial comments:This report is the result of an occupancy survey conducted May 15, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital Medical Commons One, which included the storage room. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities.  Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an occupancy survey conducted May 15, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital Medical Commons One, which included the storage room. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Ambulatory Care Facilities, Annex A, Title 28, Part IV, Subparts A and F, Chapters 551-573, November 1999 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities.  Plan of Correction:

Initial comments:This report is the result of an occupancy survey conducted on April 17, 2023, with continued document review until April 19, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital, which included Phase 1 of alterations to existing cardiac catheterization labs. Cath Lab #5, was renamed Cath Lab #4. Cath Lab #4 was updated to a Class 3 Imaging Room. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an occupancy survey conducted on April 17, 2023, with continued document review until April 19, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital, which included Phase 1 of alterations to existing cardiac catheterization labs. Cath Lab #5, was renamed Cath Lab #4. Cath Lab #4 was updated to a Class 3 Imaging Room. Based on the occupancy survey, it was determined the facility was in compliance with all applicable requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998 and the current edition of the Guidelines for Design and Construction of Hospital and Health Care Facilities. Plan of Correction:

Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite complaint investigation PIT23C001P completed on February 23, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital.  It was determined the facility was in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of an unannounced onsite complaint investigation PIT23C001P completed on February 23, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital.  It was determined the facility was in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 PA Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998. Plan of Correction:

Initial comments:This report is the result of a revisit conducted on February 23, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital as the result of a previous complaint investigation that was conducted on September 14, 2022. It was determined that the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998.   Plan of Correction: Initial comments:This report is the result of a revisit conducted on February 23, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital as the result of a previous complaint investigation that was conducted on September 14, 2022. It was determined that the facility was not in compliance with the requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Health's Rules and Regulations for Hospitals, 28 Pa Code, Part IV, Subparts A and B, November 1987, as amended June 1998.   Plan of Correction: 109.23 (b)(1-5) LICENSURE WRITTEN NURSING CARE POLICIES:109.23 (b) Nursing care policies and 
procedures shall be consistent with 
professionally recognized standards of 
nursing practice and shall be in 
accordance with the Professional 
Nursing Law and regulations 
promulgated by the State Board of 
examiners. These policies shall 
include procedures for the following:  (1) noting diagnostic and 
therapeutic orders  (2) assigning the nursing care 
of patients  (3) infection control  (4) patient safety  (5) implementing orders for 
medication and treatment, consistent 
with 107.61-107.65 of this subpart.Observations:Based of review of facility policies, review of medical records (MR), and interview with facility staff (EMP), it was determined that the facility failed to ensure that nursing care policies that are consistent with professionally recognized standards of nursing practice were followed by staff for three out of three medical records reviewed (MR1, MR2, and MR3). Findings include: On February 23, 2023, the following materials were reviewed:Staff education roster for nutritional intake documentation.Unit director chart audits for stroke patients, including nutritional intake documentation, with documentation of re-education when audit did not meet goal.Facility material titled "Technical Partner Standard Work", date unknown, revealed "...Daylight...Assist patients in eating that are in need...Document all patient intakes...Evening...Assist patients in eating that are in need...Document all patient intakes...".On February 23, 2023, MR1, MR2, and MR3 were reviewed for their entire admissions. No nutritional intake was documented for these patients. On February 23, 2023, at 12:30pm, EMP1 confirmed the above findings.  Plan of Correction - To be completed: 03/09/2023On 3/1/23, the Nursing Clinical Director confirmed that the Technical Partner Standard Work document outlines the requirement for documentation of all patients' oral intakes.  As of 3/1/2023, a laminated lime green nutritional intake visual management tool will be posted in each patient room for staff to document the patient's oral intake for each meal.  This information will be transposed into the electronic medical record by the technical partner.  The nursing staff will also be held accountable to ensure that the information is transposed into the electronic medical record.    Beginning 3/1/2023 through 3/15/2023, during daily meeting sessions, one on one coaching, and email distribution, the Nursing Clinical Director will re-educate the nursing and technical partner staff on their role and responsibility to document the patient's nutritional intake for each meal.  Additionally, the staff will be provided education on the above-mentioned visual management tool and process flow for documentation.In an effort to ensure compliance, the Nursing Clinical Director of 3E or designee will audit a random sample of thirty patient records (all stroke patients will be included in the sample) for the months of April, May, and June to ensure that staff are providing the required documentation to depict the patient's nutritional intake.  The audit period will begin 4/4/2023 and continue through 6/30/2023.  100% compliance is expected.  Any episode of non-compliance will be addressed immediately and the staff member will be re-educated on the process. The Quality Analyst will meet with the Nursing Clinical Director of 3E within the first week of May to confirm that that above plan has improved practice.  If there is not a noted improvement in performance, additional actions will be taken to ensure that 100% compliance is achieved.  To ensure ongoing compliance, the Nursing Clinical Director of 3E or designee will conduct thirty additional random audits for the third quarter of calendar year 2023.  If compliance is less than 100%, the audits will continue as described above on a monthly basis until the goal of 100% is met. 109.23 (b)(1-5) LICENSURE WRITTEN NURSING CARE POLICIES: 109.23 (b) Nursing care policies and 
procedures shall be consistent with 
professionally recognized standards of 
nursing practice and shall be in 
accordance with the Professional 
Nursing Law and regulations 
promulgated by the State Board of 
examiners. These policies shall 
include procedures for the following:  (1) noting diagnostic and 
therapeutic orders  (2) assigning the nursing care 
of patients  (3) infection control  (4) patient safety  (5) implementing orders for 
medication and treatment, consistent 
with 107.61-107.65 of this subpart. Observations:Based of review of facility policies, review of medical records (MR), and interview with facility staff (EMP), it was determined that the facility failed to ensure that nursing care policies that are consistent with professionally recognized standards of nursing practice were followed by staff for three out of three medical records reviewed (MR1, MR2, and MR3). Findings include: On February 23, 2023, the following materials were reviewed:Staff education roster for nutritional intake documentation.Unit director chart audits for stroke patients, including nutritional intake documentation, with documentation of re-education when audit did not meet goal.Facility material titled "Technical Partner Standard Work", date unknown, revealed "...Daylight...Assist patients in eating that are in need...Document all patient intakes...Evening...Assist patients in eating that are in need...Document all patient intakes...".On February 23, 2023, MR1, MR2, and MR3 were reviewed for their entire admissions. No nutritional intake was documented for these patients. On February 23, 2023, at 12:30pm, EMP1 confirmed the above findings.  Plan of Correction - To be completed: 03/09/2023On 3/1/23, the Nursing Clinical Director confirmed that the Technical Partner Standard Work document outlines the requirement for documentation of all patients' oral intakes.  As of 3/1/2023, a laminated lime green nutritional intake visual management tool will be posted in each patient room for staff to document the patient's oral intake for each meal.  This information will be transposed into the electronic medical record by the technical partner.  The nursing staff will also be held accountable to ensure that the information is transposed into the electronic medical record.    Beginning 3/1/2023 through 3/15/2023, during daily meeting sessions, one on one coaching, and email distribution, the Nursing Clinical Director will re-educate the nursing and technical partner staff on their role and responsibility to document the patient's nutritional intake for each meal.  Additionally, the staff will be provided education on the above-mentioned visual management tool and process flow for documentation.In an effort to ensure compliance, the Nursing Clinical Director of 3E or designee will audit a random sample of thirty patient records (all stroke patients will be included in the sample) for the months of April, May, and June to ensure that staff are providing the required documentation to depict the patient's nutritional intake.  The audit period will begin 4/4/2023 and continue through 6/30/2023.  100% compliance is expected.  Any episode of non-compliance will be addressed immediately and the staff member will be re-educated on the process. The Quality Analyst will meet with the Nursing Clinical Director of 3E within the first week of May to confirm that that above plan has improved practice.  If there is not a noted improvement in performance, additional actions will be taken to ensure that 100% compliance is achieved.  To ensure ongoing compliance, the Nursing Clinical Director of 3E or designee will conduct thirty additional random audits for the third quarter of calendar year 2023.  If compliance is less than 100%, the audits will continue as described above on a monthly basis until the goal of 100% is met.

Initial comments:This report is the result of a revisit conducted on January 11, 2023, at Excela Health Westmoreland Hospital as the result of a previous complaint survey that was conducted on August 15, 2022.
